Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Research Into The Origins Of Human Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sarah Hlubik of Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey, will undertake a research project to investigate when human ancestors first began using fire on a regular basis. This study addresses a crucial topic in understanding the evolution of the genus Homo. The physical changes from Australopithecus/early Homo to Homo erectus are striking, with Homo erectus being larger bodied and with a more slender trunk, indicating a change in the digestive system. This change can be explained by the regular use of fire to help prepare food. For over a decade researchers have argued this point, but there are no archaeological instances of fire in the record with the appearance of H. erectus. This study will assess the claim that the earliest fire in the record dates back to at least 1.5 million years ago (mya) through a vigorous research schedule that includes excavation and experimentation to determine the signature of fire and its longevity on the landscape.

This project explores the ways in which fire can be identified in the ancient archaeological record of open-air sites. It is based heavily on excavation, sampling, and comparison to experimental work to look at the signature of fire on the landscape and in cultural contexts, and whether it can be identified and detected in sites greater than 1 million years. The work primarily takes place in Northern Kenya.. The site of FxJj20 AB is a known site, which has so far yielded several thousand artifacts and fossil bone, and contains some suggestive evidence for the presence of fire. The site is located on floodplain sediments, with little evidence of artifact movement by water or wind, which makes it a good candidate to answer the question of whether or not fire was present and whether or not fire was maintained and controlled by the human ancestors who created the site. Excavation is conducted with small tools, enabling the recovery of all materials in their original position. Artifacts and bone are examined for possible indications of burning. Sampled materials include sedimentary columns, and loose sediment, stone, and bone samples for investigation using a Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR), which are compared with experimentally produced samples to determine whether the materials on site have been burned. Sedimentary columns are also examined through petrographic thin-sectioning to determine the specific history of the site after its creation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project looked into the possibility of fire on an early archaeological site, FxJj20 AB, in Koobi Fora, Kenya, dated to 1.5 million years old. The work found that fire was present on the site and was associated with archaeological material left by human ancestors (Homo erectus). This find is important to archaeology because it demonstrates that it is possible to find evidence for fire at early open-air (as opposed to cave) sites. The project is important to the study of human evolution because it demonstrates the possibility that archaeological evidence can be found in association with fire evidence, and that fire could have had an impact on the development of human evolution. 

The work included painstaking archaeological exacavation that attempted to recover as much material cultural evidence (stone and bone fragments) as possible. This methodology shows the importance of getting as much archaeological material as possible to identify activities on early archaeological sites, and to identify how sites were formed. The work showed that this site was likely a place where human ancestors made and used stone tools, and that the material is likely found where it was originally deposited, as opposed to being deposited by water, wind, or other animal activities. 

This work also included a rigorous sampling method to look at the chemical and geological residues of fire, using techniques from geology and geochemistry known as micromorphology (the microscopic study of sediments) and Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (the study of chemical signatures using infrared light). These techniques have been used in previous studies of potential fire evidence associated with human remains, but those studies concentrated on sites from later time periods and cave sites; they had never been tried at a site this early or from an open-air setting. The study demonstrated that the use of these techniques could positively identify fire on early archaeological sites and open the possibility that more evidence of fire associated with human activity might be found in the future. 

The figure shows a map of the site with the location of the artifacts found and materials that are thermally altered. Burned bones, potlids (burned stone) and sediment are found throughout the excavation and an alaysis of their locations shows that these things are thoroughly mixed in with the other archaeological materials. While this does not prove that our human ancestors were using fire, it strengthens the argument that they may have been. Future research into the topic may reveal more sites with similar evidence that will be able to show that this behavior was used regularly in the deep past.

This study is important because the use of fire by human ancestors may have affected the way humans evolved. Cooking softens food and releases nutirition in the form of calories, and reduces toxic and parasitic loads in both plants and animals. Food that is softer to chew and has fewer parasites or toxins would be more easily digested, and could lead to the reduction in gut size. This gut reduction would free up metabolic energy that could then be used to increase brain and body size. These changes are first seen beginning with H. erectus in the paleontological record. The use of fire as a tool has been suggested as the catalyst for the changes seen in H. erectus since the late 1990's, but archaeological evidence to support the hypothesis has been scant. Previous work hypothesizing that fire was present in the early record lacks the multidisciplinary, mutli-proxy approach to fire taken in this study. This study shows that, using many different approaches, it is possible to identify fire at very early sites. This research confirms methodology that enables the identification of fire on early sites and forms the basis for future research proposals to widen the search for early fire.
